content:
The few beginner Lean proof courses I've seen cover "discrete" maths - and that makes sense.

When I started, I set myself three targets: (1) doing proof by contradiction, (2) doing induction in Lean, and (3) doing calculus or real/complex analysis in Lean.

I've seen - albeit at a beginner level - how to do (1) and (2) now ..and having done all the relevant exercises in MoP, I feel confident enough to at least hold a conversation about these.

However I can't seem to find any beginner-friendly course/guides that take us to doing "continuous" maths with lean.

I'm not 100% sure what I mean by that but the following are example scenarios that I hope to use Lean to write proofs about:

  • proving limits eg sin(x)/x = 1 as x -> 0
  • proving a complex function is holomorphic
  • proving a real function is not continuous

that sort of thing.
I think #mil should have this, but I don't know how beginner-oriented it is

I found these notes from @Kevin Buzzard pretty useful to get a sense of what real analysis might look like - keeping in mind (e.g. from ection 12), mathlib would typically prove these theorems in more generality
Yeah after some basic logic I go straight into 1st year undergrad analysis in section 2.
The usual belief in maths departments is that you shouldn't be doing limits of functions before you've mastered limits of sequences, so that's what I do there.
Thanks, the notes on "tends to" for a sequence is what I can work towards. Thanks again,
